question: A.1 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following factors in the “six factor” formula is MOST affected by the MODERATOR?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 3.3.1,  page 3-16.
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 3.3.1,  page 3-16.
Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 3.3.1,  page 3-16.
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 3.3.1,  page 3-16.

question: A.2 [1.0 point] Change was made during the administration of the examination The injection of a sample results in a 50 millisecond period. If the scram setpoint is 250 KILOWATTS and the scram delay time is 0.1 seconds, which ONE of the following is the peak power of the reactor at scram shutdown?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982   P = P0 et/τ, P = 250 kW × e0.1/0.05 = 250 kW × e2 = 1847 kW
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982   P = P0 et/τ, P = 250 kW × e0.1/0.05 = 250 kW × e2 = 1847 kW
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982   P = P0 et/τ, P = 250 kW × e0.1/0.05 = 250 kW × e2 = 1847 kW
Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982   P = P0 et/τ, P = 250 kW × e0.1/0.05 = 250 kW × e2 = 1847 kW

question: A.3 [1.0 point] The following graph for U-235 depicts…:

answers.answer: a. axial flux distribution in the core
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Manual Vol. 1, pg.  57
Correct. Reference: DOE Manual Vol. 1, pg.  57

answers.answer: c. radial flux distribution in the core
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Manual Vol. 1, pg.  57

answers.answer: d. neutron energy distribution in the moderator
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Manual Vol. 1, pg.  57

question: A.4 [1.0 point] Two critical reactors at low power are identical, except that Reactor 1 has a beta fraction of 0.0078 and Reactor 2 has a beta fraction of 0.0065. Which ONE of the following best describes the response if an equal amount of positive reactivity is inserted into both reactors?

answers.answer: a. Period of the Reactor 1 will be longer than the period of the Reactor 2
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Equation Sheet.  τ = (ℓ*/ρ) + [(β-ρ)/λeffρ]

answers.answer: b. Period of the Reactor 1 will be shorter than the period of the Reactor 2
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Equation Sheet.  τ = (ℓ*/ρ) + [(β-ρ)/λeffρ]

answers.answer: c. Power of the Reactor 1 will be higher than the power of the Reactor 2
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Equation Sheet.  τ = (ℓ*/ρ) + [(β-ρ)/λeffρ]

answers.answer: d. Power of the Reactor 1 will be lower than the power of the Reactor 2
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Equation Sheet.  τ = (ℓ*/ρ) + [(β-ρ)/λeffρ]

question: A.5 [1.0 point] Given the following Core Reactivity Data : Control Rod Total Worth ($) Worth Removed at 1.5 watts ($) SHIM Rod 3.70 1.70 REG Rod 2.80 2.60 Adjust Transient Rod 1.80 1.50 Fast Transient Rod 0.70 0.70 Which ONE of the following is the calculated shutdown margin that would satisfy the Technical Specification Minimum Shutdown Margin? Assume that all control rods are scramable.

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Tech Spec SDM = 3total rod worth removed at critical – most reactivity control rod worth SDM = 3(B) - Max (A) = $6.50 – $3.70 = $2.80
Incorrect. Reference: Tech Spec SDM = 3total rod worth removed at critical – most reactivity control rod worth SDM = 3(B) - Max (A) = $6.50 – $3.70 = $2.80
Correct. Reference: Tech Spec SDM = 3total rod worth removed at critical – most reactivity control rod worth SDM = 3(B) - Max (A) = $6.50 – $3.70 = $2.80
Incorrect. Reference: Tech Spec SDM = 3total rod worth removed at critical – most reactivity control rod worth SDM = 3(B) - Max (A) = $6.50 – $3.70 = $2.80

question: A.7 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following is the correct amount of reactivity added if the multiplication factor, k, is increased from 0.800 to 0.950?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 3.3.3, page 3-21. In order to solve the question A.07, the applicant can use one of the following methods: At k=0.8; ρ = ∆Keff/Keff or ρ = Keff-1/Keff = -0.2/0.8 =-0.25.  At k=0.95, ρ =-0.05/0.95  ρ = -0.053.  The difference between ρ is the answer ,i.e. -0.053-(-0.25)=0.197 ∆ ρ = ρ1 – ρ2 where ρ1 = Keff1-1/Keff1 and ρ2 = Keff2-1/Keff2.  Substitute ρ1 and ρ2 with Keff1 and Keff2 into the equation above, the result is ∆ρ = keff1-keff2/(keff1 x keff2)

Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 3.3.3, page 3-21. In order to solve the question A.07, the applicant can use one of the following methods: At k=0.8; ρ = ∆Keff/Keff or ρ = Keff-1/Keff = -0.2/0.8 =-0.25.  At k=0.95, ρ =-0.05/0.95  ρ = -0.053.  The difference between ρ is the answer ,i.e. -0.053-(-0.25)=0.197 ∆ ρ = ρ1 – ρ2 where ρ1 = Keff1-1/Keff1 and ρ2 = Keff2-1/Keff2.  Substitute ρ1 and ρ2 with Keff1 and Keff2 into the equation above, the result is ∆ρ = keff1-keff2/(keff1 x keff2)

Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 3.3.3, page 3-21. In order to solve the question A.07, the applicant can use one of the following methods: At k=0.8; ρ = ∆Keff/Keff or ρ = Keff-1/Keff = -0.2/0.8 =-0.25.  At k=0.95, ρ =-0.05/0.95  ρ = -0.053.  The difference between ρ is the answer ,i.e. -0.053-(-0.25)=0.197 ∆ ρ = ρ1 – ρ2 where ρ1 = Keff1-1/Keff1 and ρ2 = Keff2-1/Keff2.  Substitute ρ1 and ρ2 with Keff1 and Keff2 into the equation above, the result is ∆ρ = keff1-keff2/(keff1 x keff2)

Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 3.3.3, page 3-21. In order to solve the question A.07, the applicant can use one of the following methods: At k=0.8; ρ = ∆Keff/Keff or ρ = Keff-1/Keff = -0.2/0.8 =-0.25.  At k=0.95, ρ =-0.05/0.95  ρ = -0.053.  The difference between ρ is the answer ,i.e. -0.053-(-0.25)=0.197 ∆ ρ = ρ1 – ρ2 where ρ1 = Keff1-1/Keff1 and ρ2 = Keff2-1/Keff2.  Substitute ρ1 and ρ2 with Keff1 and Keff2 into the equation above, the result is ∆ρ = keff1-keff2/(keff1 x keff2)

question: A.8 [1.0 point] The time period in which the MAXIMUM amount of Xe-135 will be present in the core is approximately 8 hours after:

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 8.4, page 8-9
Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 8.4, page 8-9

answers.answer: c. a power increase from 0% to 50%
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 8.4, page 8-9

answers.answer: d. a power decrease from 100% to 50%
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 8.4, page 8-9

question: A.9 [1.0 point] In a just critical reactor, adding one dollar worth of reactivity will cause:

answers.answer: a. A sudden drop in delayed neutrons
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: UCI Instruction Manual for Operators, Sec 3.2.5, page 3-12

answers.answer: b. The reactor period to be equal to (β-ρ)/λρ
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: UCI Instruction Manual for Operators, Sec 3.2.5, page 3-12

answers.answer: c. A number of prompt neutrons equals to a number of delayed neutrons
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: UCI Instruction Manual for Operators, Sec 3.2.5, page 3-12

answers.answer: d. The resultant period to be a function of the prompt neutron lifetime
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: UCI Instruction Manual for Operators, Sec 3.2.5, page 3-12

question: A.10 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following conditions will INCREASE the core excess of a reactor?

answers.answer: a. Higher moderator temperature (assume negative temperature coefficient)
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Standard NRC question

answers.answer: b. Insertion of a negative reactivity worth experiment
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Standard NRC question

answers.answer: c. Burnout of a burnable poison
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Standard NRC question
Incorrect. Reference: Standard NRC question

question: A.11 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following statements best describes on how moderator temperature affects the core operating characteristics?

answers.answer: a. Increase in moderator temperature will increase the neutron multiplication factor due to the resonance escape probability increase.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 3.3.1

answers.answer: b. Increase in moderator temperature will increase the neutron multiplication factor due to the fast non leakage probability decrease.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 3.3.1

answers.answer: c. Increase in moderator temperature will decrease the neutron multiplication factor due to the reproduction factor increase.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 3.3.1

answers.answer: d. Increase in moderator temperature will decrease the neutron multiplication factor due to the resonance escape probability decrease.
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 3.3.1

question: A.13 [1.0 point] Changes were made during the administration of the examination A reactor with Keff = 0.8 contributes 1000 neutrons in the first generation. Changing from the first generation to the SECOND generation, how many total neutrons are there in after the second generation?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 5.3, p. 5.6 2-nd generation=n + K*n=1000+800=1800 neutrons
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 5.3, p. 5.6 2-nd generation=n + K*n=1000+800=1800 neutrons
Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 5.3, p. 5.6 2-nd generation=n + K*n=1000+800=1800 neutrons
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 5.3, p. 5.6 2-nd generation=n + K*n=1000+800=1800 neutrons

question: A.14 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following isotopes has the HIGHEST thermal neutron cross section?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Table2.5, page 2-59.
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Table2.5, page 2-59.

question: A.15 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following describes the term PROMPT DROP?

answers.answer: a. A reactor is subcritical at negative 80-second period.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Page 4-21.

answers.answer: b. A reactor has attained criticality on prompt neutrons alone.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Page 4-21.

answers.answer: c. The instantaneous change in power level due to inserting a control rod.
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Page 4-21.

answers.answer: d. The instantaneous change in power level due to withdrawing a control rod.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Page 4-21.

question: A.16 [1.0 point] About two minutes following a reactor scram, the reactor period has stabilized and the power level is decreasing at a CONSTANT rate. Given that reactor power at time t0 is 100 kW power, what will it be three minutes later?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: P = P0 e-T/J = 100 kW H e(180sec/-80sec) = 100 kW H e-2.25 = 0.1054 H 100 kW = 10 kW
Correct. Reference: P = P0 e-T/J = 100 kW H e(180sec/-80sec) = 100 kW H e-2.25 = 0.1054 H 100 kW = 10 kW
Incorrect. Reference: P = P0 e-T/J = 100 kW H e(180sec/-80sec) = 100 kW H e-2.25 = 0.1054 H 100 kW = 10 kW
Incorrect. Reference: P = P0 e-T/J = 100 kW H e(180sec/-80sec) = 100 kW H e-2.25 = 0.1054 H 100 kW = 10 kW
